Situation1: They are asked to guide a mentee preparing for a critical career advancement opportunity.
Situation2: A rarely used machine shows an intermittent glitch during a slow production period.
Story:
I sat at my desk, the hum of the factory floor a familiar backdrop. My phone buzzed—a message from my mentee, Sarah. She was anxious about her upcoming interview for a team lead position, and she wanted to meet right away to go over her presentation. As her mentor, I knew how much this meant to her. She’d worked hard, and I was supposed to help her grow, to be there when she needed guidance most.

Just as I was about to reply, my supervisor called. The old packaging machine, the one that only ran during peak times, was acting up again. It was a slow day, but the glitch was unpredictable, and if I didn’t catch it now, it could halt production when we needed it most. As the only one who really understood its quirks, everyone expected me to drop everything and fix it.

I stared at my phone, then at the blinking light on my work tablet. Sarah was counting on me to help her seize a big opportunity. The team was counting on me to keep the machines running smoothly. My chest tightened as I weighed the demands, feeling pulled in two directions, knowing I couldn’t be in both places at once.
